items.q: Which sentence correctly fixes the comma splice: The clock struck midnight, it was time for the party to end.
options: The clock struck midnight; it was time for the party to end.
The clock struck midnight, and it was time for the party to end.
The clock struck midnight. It was time for the party to end.
All of the above.

items.q: Identify the sentence that contains a comma splice.
options: I prefer tea, but he prefers coffee.
The rain stopped, the sun came out.
Although she was late, she didn't miss the meeting.
Since I was tired, I went home early.

items.q: Which option correctly replaces the comma in: The movie ended, we all stood up.
options: The movie ended; then we all stood up.
The movie ended and we all stood up.
The movie ended so we all stood up.
The movie ended, and we all stood up.

items.q: The recipe calls for six eggs, however, I only have four. This sentence contains a comma splice because:
options: "however" is a coordinating conjunction.
"however" must be preceded by a period.
"however" is a conjunctive adverb, not a coordinating conjunction.
the sentence is too long.

items.q: Which punctuation mark can separate two independent clauses without using a coordinating conjunction?
options: Comma
Colon
Semicolon
Hyphen

items.q: Fix the comma splice: She studied hard for the test, therefore she earned an A.
options: She studied hard for the test. Therefore, she earned an A.
She studied hard for the test; therefore, she earned an A.
She studied hard for the test, and therefore she earned an A.
Both A and B.

items.q: The student finished her essay, then she submitted it to the professor. Is this correct?
options: Yes, because "then" is a conjunction.
No, it is a run-on sentence.
Yes, because the clauses are related.
No, it is a comma splice.

items.q: Which is the best way to fix: He loves to travel, he goes somewhere new every year.
options: He loves to travel; he goes somewhere new every year.
He loves to travel, so he goes somewhere new every year.
He loves to travel. He goes somewhere new every year.
All are acceptable, but B shows the cause/effect relationship.

items.q: A comma splice results from using a comma to separate:
options: a dependent clause and an independent clause.
two phrases.
two independent clauses.
two compound subjects.

items.q: Which fix is incorrect: The food was delicious, we ate every bite.
options: The food was delicious. We ate every bite.
The food was delicious; we ate every bite.
The food was delicious so we ate every bite.
The food was delicious, and we ate every bite.
